body: Sure thing, @piiswrong -- we've had no luck with this functionality within our internal builds, so I'm happy to follow suit until things are cleared up.

Hi Leonard:
   Although I am not a maintainer, I think you are right, just pull a request and waiting for board to review
From: Leonard [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 6, 2016 6:45 PM
To: dmlc/mxnet <mxnet@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Guo, Lingyan <lingyan.guo@intel.com>; Mention <mention@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [dmlc/mxnet] Mxnet amalgamation project rely on intel MKL? (#3667)


@fengshikun<https://github.com/fengshikun>
Thanks. In addition to blacklisting mkl I had to exclude nnpack and omp.h:

Should this be incorporated in the master branch? (And is this even correct? At least the build process for mxnet.js would run through without problems, but I haven't tested it further). If so I can prepare a pull request..

Is my understanding correct, that one has to assure that in the config.mk CUDA, CUDNN, OPENMP, MKL2017, etc. are disabled? If so I would suggest to state this in the readme.

diff --git a/amalgamation/amalgamation.py b/amalgamation/amalgamation.py

index be85418..9967ed7 100644

--- a/amalgamation/amalgamation.py

+++ b/amalgamation/amalgamation.py

@@ -7,7 +7,8 @@ blacklist = [

     'glog/logging.h', 'io/azure_filesys.h', 'io/hdfs_filesys.h', 'io/s3_filesys.h',

     'kvstore_dist.h', 'mach/clock.h', 'mach/mach.h',

     'malloc.h', 'mkl.h', 'mkl_cblas.h', 'mkl_vsl.h', 'mkl_vsl_functions.h',

-    'nvml.h', 'opencv2/opencv.hpp', 'sys/stat.h', 'sys/types.h', 'cuda.h', 'cuda_fp16.h'

+    'nvml.h', 'opencv2/opencv.hpp', 'sys/stat.h', 'sys/types.h', 'cuda.h', 'cuda_fp16.h',

+    'omp.h'

     ]



 if len(sys.argv) < 4:

@@ -87,7 +88,7 @@ def expand(x, pending):

         h = m.groups()[0].strip('./')

         source = find_source(h, x)

         if not source:

-            if h not in blacklist and h not in sysheaders: sysheaders.append(h)

+            if h not in blacklist and h not in sysheaders and 'mkl' not in h and 'nnpack' not in h: sysheaders.append(h)

         else:

             expand(source, pending + [x])

     print >>out, "//===== EXPANDED: %s =====\n" %x



â€”

Currently I am afraid you can't use `mxnet` directly.

What `shinyapp.io` does is to get the pkg from some repo, including the CRAN and github.

I believe they are using Linux as the backend, however, we don't host any Linux pkg in any repos.

I will double check with them.
@zhreshold  - can you take a look here?

I have exactly the same problem, while  in Python everything works fine using mx.model.FeedForward(), in R I struggle to extract internal convolutional layers of Inception-BN in order to easily predict them on other image input. It seems I need to use Rcpp and external libraries, for example i get using your code
"missing function mx.net.slice".

I guess CPU/disk IO may be the killing factor when data is loaded to the network. 
1. SSD example require various data augmentations which are computed on CPU, this might be a bottleneck depending how good your CPU is.
2. Again for the same reason, images are not packed to record file so IO speed(especially random access) is another factor.

I suggest you to use smaller batch-size to verify, e.g. batch 8 for 1 gpu, 16 for 2 gpu, etc...
BTW, using very large batch-size didn't beat smaller batch-size or maybe even worse based on my experience with ssd example.
@zhreshold Could you take a look at mx.image in the nnvm branch? Its a fast image preprocessing pipeline

I'm not familiar with this. Whats the difference between one-hot encoding and embedding?
If its a general layer (not specific to one project) and it can't be done with current layers we should definately add it.
@feiyulv Could you make a minimal reproducing example? What layers did you use?
I can't reproduce this bug with FasterRCNN.
@piiswrong there should be no problem to do that if people use `mod` or `module`. not sure about others

Please rebase,
make the comment in config.mk more descriptive (atleast "Please refer to MKL_README.md for details) 
verify that test_operator_gpu passes when mkl is on
and we can merge
Its equivalent to the NDArray op `mx.nd.onehot_encode(mx.nd.array(indices), out=arr)`. Its input obviously has no gradient, just like `Embedding`, but also has no weights.
Then we don't need to add a layer. We can just use onehot_encode. In nnvm branch all operators can be called from both nd and sym
Could you verify this works locally?
it should be fine. i'm going to merge and trick the build to check if everything goes well.

Isn't mx.image a wrapper for cv2? 
I guess cv2 and numpy operations are good in terms of speed for now, the priority is to pack single images into record file and feed the iterator with ImagerecordIter. 
I hope someone could confirm this behavior before I could do something. I'm too busy these days.
@tornadomeet I have uploaded the resnext101 model on model gallary

With smaller batch sizes I get the following throughput:

| No. of GPUs | Batch Size | Speed |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
| 1 | 8 | 9.9 samples/sec |
| 2 | 16 | 14.0 samples/sec |
| 4 | 32 | 21.0 samples/sec |
| 8 | 64 | 21.5 samples/sec |

With deactivated file I/O and data augmentation I get the following throughput:

| No. of GPUs | Batch Size | Speed |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
| 1 | 8 | 9.8 samples/sec |
| 1 | 32 | 11.4 samples/sec |
| 1 | 64 | 11.5 samples/sec |
| 2 | 16 | 14.5 samples/sec |
| 2 | 64 | 19.4 samples/sec | 
| 2 | 128 | 20.7 samples/sec |
| 4 | 32 | 25.3 samples/sec |
| 4 | 128 | 38.5 samples/sec |
| 4 | 256 | 40.9 samples/sec |
| 8 | 64 | 38.9 samples/sec |
| 8 | 256 | 68.3 samples/sec |
| 8 | 512 | 74.5 samples/sec |

As you said @zhreshold, the throughput is much better without file I/O and data augmentation. Would you optimize something else too to further speedup the multi-gpu training?
Ah, I was under the (mistaken) impression that all symbol ops could automatically be called to do NDArray ops, but didn't know that they other way round also held. Thanks!

@gerhardneuhold Could you disable data augmentation only in config/config.py:
```
cfg.TRAIN.RAND_SAMPLERS = []
cfg.TRAIN.RAND_MIRROR = False
cfg.TRAIN.INIT_SHUFFLE = False
cfg.TRAIN.EPOCH_SHUFFLE = False # shuffle training list after each epoch
```
Then I could have a sense of how I/O affecting the throughput, appreciated very much.
BTW, it is train on HDD instance right?

Sure @zhreshold, here are some throughput rates with disabled data augmentation only:

| No. of GPUs | Batch Size | Speed |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
| 1 | 8 | 9.9 samples/sec |
| 1 | 32 | 11.4 samples/sec |
| 2 | 16 | 14.2 samples/sec |
| 2 | 64 | 18.2 samples/sec |
| 4 | 32 | 25.5 samples/sec |
| 4 | 128 | 27.7 samples/sec |
| 8 | 64 | 28.6 samples/sec |
| 8 | 256 | 29.5 samples/sec |

Data is read from SSD (EBS io1).

@zhreshold Its a wrapper. But it bypasses GIL by pushing image decoding to engine. It also uses mx.nd instead of numpy for computation. So its much faster when you increase NUM_CPU_WORKER.

ImagerecordIter is fast not because it read from single file (it helps a little, but not that much). Its because it uses 4 thread for decoding by default.

I see. Here's my thought

- [ ] `High priority:` pack separate images to record file, modify data_iter to take images from internal ImageRecordIter. HDD users could benefit a lot from this. 

- [ ]  Replace with mx.image functions for data augmentation
seems was due to the attr parser did not get invoked (and the attr.parsed) remains empty somehow.

here is the related code https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/nnvm/src/operator/operator_common.h#L149

In theory, when MakeGradNode is called, the attribute parser will get called and set the parsed to be the result.
This can be merged now. @piiswrong

@wanderingpj  i just read the code and found my previous commit is a little wrong.  

your question is: why `_update_parmas` still need kvstore to push and pull?

first, when `kvstore="local"`, then it will copy all grdict to cpu and update the params on cpu, this is done by two stage, not one stage.   

then if the model params is too big, update the params using optimizer on cpu will be very costly, so in ```model.py``` it only aggregate gradient to cpu, not update paramters on cpu, and need copy the summed gradient back to device and update model params on device.   

last you can found if `update_on_kvstore=False`, then kvstore will have no function of optimization(only copy gradient), just ref. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L222-L223  

so you can read the code in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L105-L115, there is a two stage processe, no `else` there.
one last thing, please add the uploaded model into https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/common/modelzoo.py#L5

can you make the script do an http query?

proto2script(sys.argv[1]) returns 3 values, so I think you should chage the code
`symbol_string, output_name = proto2script(sys.argv[1])`
to
`symbol_string, output_name, input_dim = proto2script(sys.argv[1])`

@fq19851220 Please open config.mk file and uncomment the following lines:
```
WARPCTC_PATH = $(HOME)/warp-ctc
MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/warpctc/warpctc.mk
```
take care the WARPCTC_PATH is our warp-ctc path so please instead of it by your correct path.
and then rebuild mxnet by make clean && make -j

@piiswrong For this test I used K80s. On a single pascal based Titan X I get 38 samples/sec.
Try following the instructions [here](http://mxnet.io/get_started/setup.html?highlight=opencv) to build OpenCV from source. That should help.
It seems all the operator which calls nnvm::get() will fail in this case. Currently I  avoid this problem by replacing the broadcast_reduce_op and elemwise_binary_scalar_op with the master version.
@BobLiu20   è°¢è°¢

@piiswrong That was because the ratio of negative sample vs. positive sample is manually set to 3:1. When training starts, negative samples are much easier to converge, so it will stuck at 75% for a while, then slowly climb up when network successfully learned about positive samples.
++ Check whether the Scala deploy (to the maven repo) tool works.
yes, rand_r is supposed to be thread safe. Previous one actually cannot be compiled passed.
@sxjscience  @piiswrong Do you have chance to take a look at this and provide a example ASAP?  I need this to implement RNN layer based seq2seq model.

When I use the `20160531_win10_x64_gpu.7z`, I have same problem on :
Windows8.1, CUDA 8.0, cuDNN v3 or v5, VS 2015, GTX 860m.
But I do solve this problem by using this [https://github.com/yajiedesign/mxnet/releases ](https://github.com/yajiedesign/mxnet/releases) version, I follow actions:

1. Uninstall mxnet from python. (if you already install it.)
2. Download the `20161125_mxnet_x64_gpu.7z` , unpack it, copy all files into path you previous unpack `20160531_win10_x64_gpu.7z` and replace those there.
3. Do download the cuDNNv4 and unpack it into .../3rdparty/cudnn/
4. Run the `setupenv.cmd` or  set the enviornment path.
5. cd to .../python and type python setup.py install.

There is one thing to note that it requires `cudnn64_4.dll` which belongs to cuDNNv4.
@tqchen Is any thread safe? Possible race conditions?
Fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3421
This has been fixed already. Feel free to reopen it.

@chhamso I am sorry that I don't have access to any Windows machine now.

You need to considering compiling the mxnet and R-package from the source.

@miguelgfierro This can be done as a reference class in R. I give a very prototype below.

```r
cus_iter <-setRefClass("Custom.Iter", fields = "x")
cus_iter$methods(iter.next = function() {return(TRUE)})

iter <- cus_iter$new(x = 123)
iter$iter.next()
```
This has been fixed.

even though i'm agree resnet converter is worth to have, we have pre-trained resnet models on various datasets, including two on 20m images: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification#pre-trained-models
EncodeKey converts a mxnet/kvstore key into a ps-lite key. slice is used to cut a big array into multiple parts, each part goes to one server node
there is a `lr_scheduler`, which decides how to change the learning rate. you can has a customized scheduler which gives different lr for different nodes
you can create a kvstore type with etcd as the backend. i'm not familar with etcd, i thought etcd's main feature is robustness, not performance
not yet, you can try to implement a kubernetes tracker in https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/tree/master/tracker/dmlc_tracker it's fairly straightfoward

It works for me, Thanks

Etcd was designed for performance.The read performance is almost same as redis.The write performance is also pretty good,althogh it is poorer than redis.But redis was designed for cache,so redis does not guarantee persistence,but etcd guarantees.
The follow link is the etcd performance doc:
https://github.com/coreos/etcd/blob/master/Documentation/op-guide/performance.md
So I think that etcd is suitable for mxnet.I will try to use etcd to replace kvstore for mxnet.

@lji72 you can try this code .Maybe it is not the best  method to do so .It is  just a reference.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
#-*- coding: UTF-8 -*-
# %matplotlib inline
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import mxnet as mx
import logging
import numpy as np
from skimage import io, transform
import argparse 

parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='load model trained befor and give prediction for .rec file')
parser.add_argument('--prefix', type=str, default='./saved_model/jd_50_vgg' ,
                    help='load model structure by name which has a prefix')
parser.add_argument('--iter', type=int, default=318,
                    help='load model weight from iteration')
parser.add_argument('--shape', type=int, default=50,
                    help='data shape of .rec files')
parser.add_argument('--rgb', type=int, default=3,
                    help='color , 1 for gray,3 for color image')
parser.add_argument('--data-file', type=str, default='./data/pred_50.rec',
                    help='prediction .rec file path')
parser.add_argument('--min-file', type=str, default='./data/pred_50.min',
                    help='prediction images mean file')
parser.add_argument('--list-file', type=str, default='./data/pred.lst',
                    help='prediction images lst file')
parser.add_argument('--layer', type=str, default='fc7',
                    help='layer you want to visualize')
args = parser.parse_args()

logger = logging.getLogger()
logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
# prepare data
data_shape = (args.rgb, args.shape,args.shape)    
images = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(  
        path_imgrec = args.data_file,
        mean_img    = args.min_file,  
        rand_crop   = False,  
        rand_mirror = False, 
        shuffle     = False, 
        data_shape  = data_shape,  
        batch_size  = 1) 

# Load the pre-trained model
model = mx.model.FeedForward.load(args.prefix, args.iter)

# get internals from model's symbol
internals = model.symbol.get_internals()
# get feature layer symbol out of internals
layer = args.layer+'_output'
fea_symbol = internals[layer]
# Make a new model by using an internal symbol. We can reuse all parameters from model we trained before
# In this case, we must set ```allow_extra_params``` to True
# Because we don't need params from FullyConnected symbol
feature_extractor = mx.model.FeedForward(ctx=mx.cpu(), symbol=fea_symbol, numpy_batch_size=1,
                                         arg_params=model.arg_params, aux_params=model.aux_params,
                                         allow_extra_params=True)
# predict feature
global_pooling_feature = feature_extractor.predict(images)

a = np.asarray(global_pooling_feature)
 #
np.savetxt('./pred_'+args.layer+'.csv',a)

print  global_pooling_feature.shape
print  global_pooling_feature[0].shape
-----------------------------------------------------------

NOTE:you have to create .rec file for your images , A pre-trained model(both son and weight file).
Then pass them to this program.
